qas.question: Who was the last king of the Jagiellonian dynasty?
What stopped after the death of Sigismund II Augustus?

answers.text: monarchs could be elected from within only the royal family

qas.question: After 1573 who could become a polish-lithuanian monarch?

answers.text: any Polish noble or foreigner of royal blood

qas.question: How many documents should the new elected king sign?
What was contained in the Henrican articles and the Pacta conventa?

context: Until the death of <a0_0>Sigismund II Augustus<a0_0/>, the last king of the Jagiellonian dynasty, <a1_0>monarchs could be elected from within only the royal family<a1_0/>. However, starting from 1573, practically <a2_0>any Polish noble or foreigner of royal blood<a2_0/> could become a Polish–Lithuanian monarch. Every newly elected king was supposed to sign <a3_0>two documents<a3_0/>—the Pacta conventa ("agreed pacts")—a confirmation of the king's pre-election promises, and Henrican articles (artykuły henrykowskie, named after the first freely elected king, Henry of Valois). The latter document served as a virtual Polish constitution and contained the <a4_0>basic laws of the Commonwealth<a4_0/>:
